anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who win road march in trinidad and tobago
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n']

To better understand the question regarding who wins the Road March in Trinidad and Tobago, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This will help clarify the context and significance of the Road March competition, as well as notable winners and their contributions to the cultural landscape of Trinidad and Tobago.

### Extracted Content:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Road March title is a prestigious award in Trinidad Carnival, with historical significance dating back to 1955 when the rules were amended to restrict eligible songs to those performed by local artists. This indicates the importance of local culture and artistry in the competition.

2. **Notable Winners**:
   - **Lord Kitchener**: Holds the record for the most Road March titles with eleven wins. This highlights his prominence in the calypso genre and the cultural heritage of Trinidad and Tobago.
   - **Super Blue and Machel Montano**: Both have ten wins, showcasing their significant impact on the soca music scene.
   - **Calypso Rose**: The first female winner in 1977, she broke gender barriers in a male-dominated field. Her wins in consecutive years (1977 and 1978) emphasize her influence and the evolving role of women in Trinidadian music.
   - **Fay-Ann Lyons**: A three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to win multiple titles, she represents contemporary success in the soca genre and has made history by winning multiple prestigious titles in a single year.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March competition is not just a musical contest; it reflects the cultural identity and artistic expression of Trinidad and Tobago. The evolution of the competition, including the inclusion of female artists and the establishment of the "Calypso Monarch" title, indicates a progressive shift in the cultural landscape.

4. **Competition Structure**:
   - The Road March title is part of the broader Carnival festivities, which are integral to Trinidadian culture. The competition's rules and the types of music eligible for consideration (local artists only) underscore the importance of local talent and cultural authenticity.

### Role of Extracted Content:

- **Cultural Understanding**: The historical context and notable winners provide insight into the significance of the Road March title within Trinidadian society. Understanding who has won and the impact of their contributions helps frame the competition as a reflection of cultural pride and artistic achievement.
  
- **Gender Dynamics**: The mention of female winners, particularly Calypso Rose and Fay-Ann Lyons, highlights the changing dynamics within the music industry in Trinidad and Tobago, showcasing the increasing recognition and success of women in a traditionally male-dominated field.

- **Artistic Legacy**: The achievements of artists like Lord Kitchener, Super Blue, and Machel Montano illustrate the legacy of calypso and soca music, which are central to the identity of Trinidad and Tobago. Their multiple wins signify not only personal success but also the enduring popularity and evolution of these musical genres.

In summary, the extracted content enriches the understanding of the Road March competition by providing historical context, highlighting key figures, and illustrating the cultural significance of the event in Trinidad and Tobago. This background knowledge is essential for answering questions about the competition and its winners effectively.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. Here’s a breakdown of the key points and their implications for reasoning and inference:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Road March title is prestigious in Trinidad Carnival.
   - The rules were amended in 1955 to restrict eligibility to local Trinidad & Tobago artistes after a non-local song won.

2. **Notable Winners**:
   - Lord Kitchener has the most wins (11).
   - Super Blue and Machel Montano each have 10 wins.
   - The Mighty Sparrow has 8 wins.
   - Calypso Rose was the first female winner in 1977 and won again in 1978.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and is notable for winning multiple titles in 2009.

3. **Significant Achievements**:
   - Calypso Rose's wins led to the renaming of the "Calypso King" competition to "Calypso Monarch" to be inclusive of female participants.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is recognized for being the first female to win multiple Road March titles and for achieving a unique triple win in 2009.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The amendment of rules following a non-local win illustrates how outcomes (a foreign song winning) can lead to changes in regulations (restricting eligibility). This teaches the model to recognize cause-and-effect relationships in competitive contexts.

2. **Identifying Patterns**:
   - The repeated wins by certain artists (e.g., Lord Kitchener, Fay-Ann Lyons) can help the model infer patterns of success in competitions, such as the importance of local cultural relevance and the impact of gender representation in the arts.

3. **Social Dynamics**:
   - The evolution of the competition (e.g., the renaming of the "Calypso King" to "Calypso Monarch") reflects societal changes regarding gender roles. This can enhance the model's ability to understand social dynamics and their influence on cultural events.

4. **Comparative Analysis**:
   - By comparing the achievements of various artists, the model can learn to make logical inferences about factors contributing to success in competitive environments, such as talent, cultural resonance, and historical significance.

5. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - The timeline of events (e.g., when rules were changed, when women first won) allows the model to practice temporal reasoning, understanding how past events influence current practices and outcomes.

The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. question_info.question: who win road march in trinidad and tobago
passages:
After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children's Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.
Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.
Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.
Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
